ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

What is your overall assessment of this course?

I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We met once a week via Zoom for a group discussion/seminar.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I continued to develop my understanding of the ancient Egyptian language and grammatical structure.

I learned so much about ancient Egyptian culture, language, and grammar. Although I came in having taken L1/L2 hieroglyphs, I learned so much more about the language and the culture/history of Egypt with JCD. It was great to learn about how and why many of the rock inscriptions we read were created, and I gained a lot of perspective about "normal" or minor Egyptians and how their society operated in addition to learning to recognize many grammatical forms and new words.
I have a better understanding of Ancient Egyptian culture, and I am better at reading and understanding hieroglyphic texts.
How to apply grammatical knowledge and critical thinking to translate ancient Egyptian rock inscriptions.
How to analyze and translate Middle Egyptian language in the hieroglyphic writing system and in hieratic

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course translated very well to the online format!

The strength of this course is the professor, who is extremely entertaining (even over Zoom), knowledgeable, and even though he cold-calls all the time, never made me feel out of my depth or stupid. The only weakness is that we had basically no academic assessments and I have truly no idea what my final grade is going to be.

One of the strengths of this course is how much time is devoted to reading and translating Middle Egyptian texts, putting what you learned about the language into practice. I would have appreciated a bit of time devoted to a review of grammar, especially since Professor Darnell talks about Egyptian grammar slightly differently from what we learned in our earlier Egyptian language classes.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Because the nature of the course is us discussing our transcriptions and translations of ancient texts, it works very well in a virtual format.

I was impressed with how well this class succeeded over Zoom. We mainly read translations during class, and although only one person could read at a time, I felt that most of the class was pretty engaged throughout class time.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Prof. Darnell is an extremely engaging professor.

Totally! If you are an Egyptian student, keep taking these text seminars. JCD is so fun to take classes with, and this course never had me stressed, even when I had translated something completely wrong and had no idea what was going on. You learn so much through osmosis without even realizing that you're learning it, until the end of the semester when you look back at things you did in the first week and wonder how you could've found them difficult.
Yes. Professor Darnells excitement and enthusiasm for ancient Egypt is contagious. As a STEM major, this course provided a much needed change of pace from my regular courseload

This course focuses almost entirely on reading ancient Egyptian rock inscriptions. If you like translating Egyptian texts and then seeing how good your translation is, learning more Egyptian, this is a great course for you. Rock inscriptions are one of Professor Darnell's specialties, which means he has a lot of insights into the material that help you get a lot more out of it. These inscriptions are not as conventional as some of the other Egyptian texts out there, and each tells you lots of interesting things about life in ancient Egypt. Hieratic can be difficult, but if you put in the work, it starts to make sense.
